The chase took them all over the world, from the shadows of city alleys to the ruins of long forgotten civilizations. The Nobody was cunning, but the Woman of Scars was relentless. She pushed her team to their limits, using every trick and tool at her disposal to track him down.

Finally, they cornered the Nobody in an abandoned temple in the heart of the Brazillian jungle. The Woman of Scars and her team confronted the reality bender, ready to end his reign of terror. The battle was intense, a clash of magic and steel, as the Woman of Scars and the Nobody clashed in a test of strength and power.

In the end, it was the Woman of Scars who emerged victorious. With a final burst of power, she banished the Nobody to the void beyond time and space, ending his threat to the world.
But even as the Woman of Scars and her team celebrated their victory, the question remained: was the Nobody justified in his actions, or was he being foolish, childish, and wicked in his wanton abuse of his powers? The answer was not clear. Some saw him as a hero, fighting against a corrupt and decadent system. Others saw him as a monster, a being who was putting the lives of millions at risk.

In the end, the Woman of Scars and the GOC disappeared back into the shadows, their work done. The world was left to pick up the pieces, to try to make sense of what had happened and what was to come. But one thing was certain: the Nobody had left his mark, a scar on the fabric of reality that would never fully heal.

posts.name: AMA (not a LARP)
posts.sub: I believe I was telepathically contacted by aliens
posts.com:
Who am I: a deeply flawed, imperfect person and young man.

What did I experience: what felt like telepathic contact with aliens. Prophetic visions and fantasies later verified shortly after in life, from small/random details, to seeing a car flip over on the road in a daydream reverie and going out to help the drivers (the night after this, my dad told me he was driving somewhere at night, saw a car veer off the side and flip over by the road in front of him, and pulled over to help them, luckily they were unharmed), to a vision of the pandemic, a totalitarian plot to enslave and depopulate the world, and dissenters being harshly mocked and excluded from society as “insane or bigoted/hateful conspiracy theorists,” shortly before the pandemic.

Why do I think this happened: I can’t say for sure, but think it’s possible that I’ve been subconsciously influenced and primed by ETs for experiences like these since childhood. As a teenager I had a spiritual awakening which led to me heavily diving into esotericism, occultism, mysticism, the study of world religions and philosophy for years, along with other massive synchronicities associated with my own studies into these.

>Q: do you think you’re a “special person” “Starseed,” “have special abilities,” “are some type of uniquely bestowed teacher, leader, messiah, guru prophet or gift to humanity?”

Absolutely not. I’m just another person. I’m far from a hero and did not react to these events bravely — they gave me a nervous breakdown and made me depressed for years, but I mainly and fortunately recovered in about the past year (which was also seen in my vision, that I would struggle with mental illness for years then recover and even flourish).

AMA if you will. Sorry for the lengthy essay/blog post. Again, I can not claim to be omniscient and may not even be a good oracle or source of info on everything — just what I know, or, failing that, think I know.

posts.name: AMA (not a LARP)
posts.com:
Some stuff that might get the thread going:

I believe there are such things as “books of power,” to rework some terms from the shamanic tradition described by Carlos Castaneda in his works. Basically, books endowed by the author’s experiences, wisdom, and supernatural experiences, with a type of power which can awaken dormant energies and tendencies towards having these same or similar experiences, in receptive readers. Books that can act like a blessing or a curse.

So what does this mean? In fact, it’s a similar worldview to both occultists on the one hand, and traditional religious followers on the other, except with different values attached to it (like, “Reading books on magic, the occult, esotericism, UFOs, etc. can open you to demonic possession, but reading the Holy Scriptures is good and puts you under God’s influence,” like some fundamentalist Christians say, or, conversely, “Deeply studying and practicing what’s in these books can actually lead to ‘magic.’”)

So what are some “books of power” (whether malevolent or benevolent)? Works like Philip K. Dick’s “VALIS.” Robert Anton Wilson’s “Cosmic Trigger” and other works of his. I in fact was reading “Cosmic Trigger” when the events started overtly happening, which scared the shit out of me, because it’s exactly what RAW was talking about in that book — his paranormal experiences, synchronicities, and sense of communicating with hyper-intelligent extraterrestrial beings.

The Carlos Castaneda books, as just mentioned. Whitley Strieber’s “Communion” and his other works, & works in general of or about alien contactees and/or abductees (Dr. John Mack’s “Abduction” and other works, Budd Hopkins’s collected works on alien abduction and interviews of those claiming to have undergone it, Col. Wendelle C. Stevens’s massive collection of works on the same, other works of/about alien contactees like Betty Andreasson/“The Andreasson Affair”, etc.)

posts.name: AMA (not a LARP)
posts.com:
Religious texts and scriptures in general (Upanishads, Gitas, the Torah, the Old and New Testaments, the Koran, Buddhist sutras …). Some of esotericism, mysticism, and the occult — Kenneth Grant’s Typhonian tradition, the Gurdjieff Fourth Way teachings, Theosophy, Anthroposophy, and so forth.

Some other conspiracy/alien literature like the Montauk Books by Preston Nichols, Peter Moon and some other figure(s) at times. David Icke’s books. It could go on for quite a while.

Mentioning of a book is not endorsement of that book or everything in that book. There could easily be (and undoubtably is) lots of hogwash or horse-shit scattered in some of these books, while they still have overall merit and value.

Other historical alien contactees include:

Parmenides of Elea, the Ancient Greek Presocratic philosopher, who lived around the 6th to the 5th century BC. The legend he himself handed down in his philosophical poem, the major remaining source we have of his teachings, has him receiving a revelation from an unnamed, golden-haired goddess who whisks him into the heavens in a luminous chariot. She then explains to him how the mortals of Earth live in distorted pseudo-realities, with warring, fragmentary, conflicted cultures which obscure the Truth (ἀλήθεια, Aletheia), hence only having access to their own spurious Opinion (δόξα, Doxa).

The “Way of Truth” the goddess reveals to him, is based off of a seemingly simple yet most profound axiom: “Being is.” Only Being exists, and non-Being does not exist. This, Parmenides uses as a launching point for a
monist philosophy expounding on the oneness of Being, similar to the philosophy and theology of the Vedas. In New Age parlance, Parmenides reached “cosmic consciousness” and tried to share it with others.
